title: Will Newcastle United's recruitment be affected by Brexit? New calls for football to be 'exempt'

New calls for football to be 'exempt' Premier League and EFL clubs fear Brexit will lead to a tightening on immigration controls, impacting on the recruitment of European players Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now IN FULL: Theresa May's statement as she triggers Article 50 Share this video Get Newcastle United FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Brexit looks set to impact upon just about every aspect of life in the United Kingdom - and Premier League and EFL clubs will certainly not be exempt. 
Newcastle United have recruited heavily from the Continent in recent years, most particularly from across in France, and any restrictions on immigration will affect the Magpies’ ability to sign players from Europe. 
New immigration controls are likely to be introduced from March 2019 onwards and, though Chancellor Philip Hammond has promised “highly-skilled and highly-paid workers” will not be prevented from moving to the UK, EU footballers will need to satisfy strict work-permit rules regarding international appearances. 
The likes of Ayoze Perez , Tim Krul and Siem de Jong would not have been eligible to sign for clubs in Britain without the EU’s pillar of freedom of movement for labour having been in place. 
Premier League clubs are determined to ensure restrictions do not apply to the recruitment of top-level players going forward though, with West Ham United co-chairman David Gold and Stoke City owner Peter Coates challenging the Government to ensure an “exemption” for football. 
“The bottom line is that the Premier League is the greatest league in the world,” Gold, quoted in The Daily Mail, explained. Read More David Gold comments on Slaven Bilic's future after reports linking Rafa Benitez with West Ham 
“It’s a fantastic advert for Britain and for England. 
“I know people talk about the wealth that’s there, but these guys are on huge salaries and all the tax is going into the exchequer. 
“Why would you stifle that? Why would you want that to change? 
“The Premier League goes around the world and it’s ever expanding. 
“I don’t see a government doing something potty to disturb that.” Read More Sir Alex Ferguson: Newcastle's a great football area - Geordies travel well, that impresses me 
Interestingly, while other sectors may be affected by a tightening of immigration standards, Stoke owner Coates hopes the Premier League and EFL are excepted. 
Coates added: “We would expect footballers to be included in the exempt list- but we have to wait and see. 
“I think the Government’s got more on its hands than worrying about the Premier League. 
“They’ve no more idea than I have of what’s going to happen. 
“But hopefully football will find a way of looking after itself when it finally happens whenever that will be. 
“It could be years down the line.” Like us on Facebook
